 The whole debate is actually quite absurd, as the two participants have no Earthly business mixing aside from the fact that occasionally they endeavor to answer the same big questions. But the questions do not exist in the same realm. It's almost like a man who broke his foot after a negligent driver ran over it. Now we have a problem: the broken foot. Two men, a doctor and a lwayer, happen to be standing there while it happens. The doctor wants to tend to the foot and the lawyer wants to find the guy who did it. The doctor and the lawyer both start bickering over who should take presidence. Clearly, the foot must receive medical attention. By the same token, the victim is deserving of some restitution for his damages. It's not as apparent in my analogy as you might think as to which need is more crucial at which time, either. While the man might be in great pain, he may also be producing enough adrenaline to ignore it has he shakes his fist in the air at the unknown car now screeching around the corner. At this time, the answer is clear: the doctor needs to settle the patient down long enough to be able to examine the extent of damage on the foot. The lawyer needs to dash around the corner and see if he can catch the license plate, then start interviewing possible eyewitnesses. But in my analogy neither the doctor nor the lawyer are doing their jobs: both are bickering about which is more important, which is more needed, which is more correct: treatment or restitution.

 Take for example, you're working in a lab, and you want to describe a newly discovered bacteria. You look into the microscope, you see the little bugs moving around in an 'agitated' manner.  There is evidence, and then there is evidence.
 
 There is evidence for Darwinian theory, only if you make massive leaps of assumption... hence the same evidence can be used to say that man evolved in a certain lineage, whilst using the same evidence, other scientists may come up with a completely different lineage. This is because the pieces of evidence don't easily fit together in any discernable way. They can, like a deck of cards, be re-shuffled.
 
 It happens with the question of the ascent of Man, and with Ammonites, and with birds, and with horses etc. Evolution's evidences can be remarkably well-suited to a plethora of schools of thought.
 
 Archaeopteryx was originally thought to be on the direct line from reptile/dinosaur to birds, now it's been moved off into a quiet cul-de-sac... an evolutionary dead-end. What has changed about Archaeopteryx? Nothing really, as the fossils were found more than 100 years ago. (Nothing about the bird breathing system is ever raised because that provides even greater problems).
 
 The fluidity of 'proof' is why it is so hard to argue against evolution, because
 a) not all evolutioanries agree to any one set of terms
 or
 b) they will always retreat to the realm of 'well, it might just have happened that way'.
 
 There is evidence to suggest that animals gradually changed over a very long period of time. But the same evidence can be used to suggest that animals changed rapidly over relatively short periods of time.
 
 
 
 Here is a short list of changed theories.
 "Homo sapiens neanderthalensis (Neanderthal man) - 150 years ago Neanderthal reconstructions were stooped and very much like an 'ape-man'. It is now admitted that the supposedly stooped posture was due to disease and that Neanderthal is just a variation of the human kind.
 Ramapithecus - once widely regarded as the ancestor of humans, it has now been realised that it is merely an extinct type of orangutan (an ape).
 Eoanthropus (Piltdown man) - a hoax based on a human skull cap and an orangutan's jaw. It was widely publicized as the missing link for 40 years.
 Hesperopithecus (Nebraska man) - based on a single tooth of a type of pig now only living in Paraguay.
 Pithecanthropus (Java man) - now renamed to Homo erectus.
 Australopithecus africanus - this was at one time promoted as the missing link. It is no longer considered to be on the line from apes to humans. It is very ape-like.
 Sinanthropus (Peking man) was once presented as an ape-man but has now been reclassified as Homo erectus."
